prop.head.label.name: Part
prop.head.headtext: Handling Cases Before the Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation

prop.head.label.name: Chapter
prop.head.headtext: Factors in Deciding Whether Transfer Is Appropriate

head.headtext: Factors militating against transfer—Avoidance of end-run around trial judges

para.paratext: The Panel will not permit transfer to be a means to avoid the rulings of trial judges. Clearly the Panel will not give weight to an argument that transfer is appropriate because of the rulings of the trial courts in which actions are then pending.[1] The Panel will reject consideration of this factor outright.[2] Most probably, however, the Panel will become strongly disinclined to order transfer of any action in which this factor is either an articulated or suspected reason for the transfer motion.[3] It is thus also a factor that militates against transfer.
Maslon Edelman Borman & Brand, LLP, Minneapolis, Minnesota.
This factor is rejected by the Panel and is discussed in § 5:41.

See, e.g., In re Thomas E. Noble Litigation, 223 F. Supp. 3d 1332 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2016); In re Wells Fargo Inspection Fee Litigation, 158 F. Supp. 3d 1366 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2016); In re: Kissi, 923 F. Supp. 2d 1367 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2013) (perceived bias of judges is not a reason for transfer); In re Homemakers Franchise Litigation, 337 F. Supp. 1342 (J.P.M.L. 1972).

See, e.g., In re Isidoro Rodriguez Litigation, 829 F. Supp. 2d 1379 (J.P.M.L. 2011) (denying motion by pro se party seeking transfer to W.D. Wash or an “impartial panel” of judges outside 2d, 3rd, 4th, 5th and D.C. Circuits); In re Buesgens Litigation, 483 F. Supp. 2d 1357, 1357 (J.P.M.L. 2007) (Panel rejects request to transfer to Disitrict of the District of Columbia “or any district other than the Western District of Texas that is outside the 5th Circuit”); In re 7-Eleven Franchise Antitrust Litigation, 358 F. Supp. 286, 287 (J.P.M.L. 1973); In re Motion Picture “Standard Accessories” and “Pre-Vues” Antitrust Litigation, 339 F. Supp. 1278 (J.P.M.L. 1972).
